title: Promotion Break-Even Calculator
description: Determine if a promotion is actually worth the extra hours and responsibility by calculating your new effective hourly rate.
methodSummary: Calculates hourly rate before and after adjusting for total hours and new costs.
Break-even Salary = The salary required to maintain your previous hourly rate with the new workload.
assumptions: Base week is 40 hours unless adjusted by extra hours.
Mental load hours account for time spent thinking about work outside of direct hours.
insights: A 10% raise with a 15% increase in total time spent (including mental load) is effectively a pay cut per hour.
The 'Break-even' salary is often much higher than people expect when responsibilities scale.

faqs.a: It's the time you spend stressed about work, answering emails on weekends, or 'off-the-clock' thinking that a promotion often demands.
It's the minimum salary you should accept to ensure your hourly rate doesn't drop due to the increased workload.

faqs.q: How do I estimate extra responsibility hours?
faqs.a: Consider how much of your evening or weekend is spent 'monitoring' work or managing people effectively.

faqs.q: Does this tool account for taxes?
faqs.a: It uses gross salary. Remember that moving to a higher tax bracket might further reduce your real take-home pay.

faqs.q: Should I accept a promotion if hourly rate drops?
faqs.a: Only if the long-term career growth or resume benefit outweighs the immediate loss of time and hourly value.
If the promotion requires more days in office or a different location, enter the annual cost change in the dedicated field.
